intro: Abelia × grandiflora, commonly known as the Chinese abelia, is a deciduous shrub native to China. It features showy, tubular flowers that range in color from white to pink and red, blooming in late spring to early summer. The plant has opposite, ovate to lance-shaped leaves that are medium green and turn reddish in the fall. It thrives in partial shade to full sun and prefers well-drained, moist soil. Abelia × grandiflora is valued for its ornamental appeal and adaptability to various garden conditions.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abelia × grandiflora is primarily native to the eastern and southeastern United States. It is found in states such as North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, and Tennessee. This plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in woodland areas or along stream banks. It thrives in partial to full sunlight and is commonly found in the coastal plain regions. Its native range includes areas with a temperate climate and humid conditions.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abelia × grandiflora was mainly introduced to the United States and Europe as an ornamental plant due to its attractive flowers and hardy nature. It is commonly found in gardens and landscaped areas, particularly in temperate climates. The plant is valued for its fragrant, tubular flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in partial shade to full sun and prefers well-drained soil. Due to its adaptability, it has become naturalized in some regions outside its native range.
